h i g h l i g h t s
We introduce organic nanoclay to prepare nanocomposite pour point depressant. POA/clay nanocomposite could further improve the rheological properties of crude oil. The addition of nanoclay fosters the precipitation of wax crystals. Adding nanocomposite PPD results in the formation of larger and compact wax crystals. A possible heterogeneous nucleation mechanism for POA/clay nanocomposite is proposed.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
Introduction of nanomaterials constitutes a novel and efficient means to enhance the performance of polymeric pour point depressants (PPDs). Based on the specific layered structure and favorable cationic exchange characteristics of nano-clay particles in the presence of charged organic compounds, an original hydrophilic nano-clay is first modified by octadecyltrimethyl ammonium chloride (OTAC) and then bypolyoctadecylacrylate (POA). The modified nano-clay serves as an effective nanocomposite PPD. Compared to an identical content of POA, addition of POA/clay nanocomposite PPD to Changqing waxy crude oil improves the rheological properties while elevating the wax appearance temperature of the oil. Polarized microscope observation shows that POA/clay nanocomposites provide wax nucleation sites upon which wax molecules assemble and precipitate. Addition of POA/clay nanocomposite PPD results in larger and more compact crystal morphology, thus inhibiting the formation of a network structure, and further improving rheological properties of waxy crude oil.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Precipitation of paraffin waxes with carbon numbers C16–C40 fromwaxy crude oils greatly complicates the low temperature flow properties of the oils, generating difficulties in pipeline transportation of the oils [1,2]. A well-recognized and efficient solution to these problems is deployment of polymeric additives such as pour point depressants (PPDs) and flow improvers (FIs) [3]. PPDs/FIs doped in waxy crude oils could modify crystal growth habits by nucleation, adsorption and co-crystallization effects, effectively inhibiting the tendency of wax crystals to interconnect into fixed three-dimensional networks [4,5]. Consequently, pour point, viscosity and yield stress values of waxy crude doped with PPDs/FIs are substantially reduced. 1 Comb-like polymers, such as polyacrylates and alkyl maleic anhydridecopolymers, havebeen thoroughlystudiedasPPDsofwaxy crudeoils anddiesel oils. Effects of alkyl side chain length, polar group typeandcontent,molecularweight, oil phasecompositionon theefficiency of comb-like PPDs have been elucidated [6–9]. Results show that alkyl chain length is a crucial factor influencing the efficiency of comb-like PPDs. In addition, some researchers added polar groups and benzene rings to structure of comb-like PPDs to enhance interactions with asphaltene, which is shown to increase the field performance of the PPDs [10]. Poly (octadecyl acrylate) (POA) is an effective comb-like PPD for waxy crudes, appearing to favor formation of island defects on paraffin wax surfaces, which exhibit weak interactionswith the surrounding crystal and, therefore, act as impurity sites for blocking growth steps [11,12]. Although the poly (octadecylacrylate)hasbeenwidelyapplied inpipe transportofwaxy crude, its efficiency needs further improvement [5].
With the recent development of nanotechnology, polymer/inorganic nanocomposites or nano-hybrid materials have become the focus of significant R&D endeavors in the 21st century [13,14]. By introducing inorganic nanoparticles into polymeric matrices, resultant properties (i.e. mechanical, thermal, magnetic, and electrical) are vastly improved. Enlightened by advances in polymer/ inorganic nanocomposites, researchers developed nano-hybrid PPDs by dispersing nanoparticles into polymeric PPD matrices. Wang et al. [15] prepared a nano-hybrid PPD and compared its efficiency with traditional ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) PPDs. Rheological results showed that nano-hybrid PPD exhibits improved pour point depression efficiency in comparison to the corresponding EVA. Yang et al. [16] prepared a nano-hybrid PPD by directly dispersing hydrophilic nano-silica into POA PPDs. Compared with POA-based PPDs, nano-hybrid PPD further reduces gelation point, viscosity and yield stress of synthetic waxy oils. Microscopic images of precipitated wax crystals demonstrate that POA/nanosilica hybrids provide spherical-like templates for wax precipitation, imparting a large and compact morphology of precipitated wax crystals, suppressing gelation and improving flowability of the oil. The authors also observed in the experiment that the efficiency of nano-hybrid PPD was not stable and decreased with rest time to the efficiency of pure POA in the end. This was perhaps because POA molecules adsorbed on the surface of silica desorb into oil phase due to the incompatibility of hydrophobic POA molecules and hydrophilic nano-silica. Therefore, the surface of nanoparticles should be properly modified so as to strengthen interaction between polymeric PPDs and nano-particles.
Organically modified nano-cla .114
Montmorillonite (MMT) nano-clay is a layered silicate mineral with a 2:1 type layer structure, i.e., it has two tetrahedral sheets sandwichinga centraloctahedral sheet [17].Due to isomorphous substitution, thenano-clay isnegatively charged and somehydratedNa+ orK+ species exist in the interlayer in order to balance the negative charge [18]. Surfactants such as quaternary ammonium salt surfactants, are often used to modify nano-clay such that organic cations replace the interlayer hydrated Na+ or K+, i.e., cation exchange, enlarging layer spacing and enhancing lipophilicity of the nano-clay. In this way, the organic nano-clay (abbreviated as organic nano-clay) is easier to disperse in a polymer matrix. In past decades, organic nano-clay has been introduced into polymer matrices to form polymer/clay nanocomposites (PCN) [19,20]. Due to imbibed nano-clay, PCN properties suchasmechanical strength and thermal tolerance are superior to thoseofpristinepolymers. Becauseof the specific layered structure and simple organicmodification of MMT nano-clay, a POA/MMT clay nanocomposite PPD is developed in this work. Rheological beneficiation for Changqing waxy crude oil is evaluated. The nano-clay is first organically modified by cation exchange to improve its lipophilicity and to enhance the interaction between nano-clay and POA. Subsequently, POA/clay nanocomposite is prepared by solvent blending. The effect of POA/clay nanocomposite PPD on wax appearance temperature (WAT), rheological parameters, and morphology of precipitated wax crystals of Changqing waxy crude oil is thoroughly investigated by DSC, rheometry and microscopic observation. The beneficiation mechanism of nanocomposite PPD on crude oil rheology is also discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Deionized water was purified by reverse osmosis. Dodecane, toluene, ethanol, octadecyl acrylate, octadecyl trimethyl ammonium chloride (OTAC) and 2,20-Azobis(2-methylpropionitrile) (AIBN) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. of China. Chemical purities were all analytical or chemical pure grade (with the purity P98 wt%). The comb-like POA PPDs were synthesized by solvent free-radical polymerization of octadecyl acrylate under a nitrogen atmosphere with AIBN as the initiator and toluene as the solvent [16]. The average molecular weight of POA tested by gel permeation chromatography (GPC) was 20,000 Da. MMT nano-clay was purchased from Hengshi Mineral Processing Co. in China. The cation exchange capacity (CEC) of nano-clay is 98 mmol/100 g.
The crude oil was kindly provided by Changqing oilfield in China. As shown in Table 1, the crude oil contains a large content of saturates (66.89 wt%) and aromatics (23.51 wt%), while the content of resins (8.78 wt%) and asphaltenes (0.82 wt%) are relatively small. The initial boiling point of the crude oil is relatively low (56 C), while the wax content (15.35 wt%) and pour point (28 C) is relatively high. Fig. 1 shows the crude oil has a wide n-alkane distribution (C8–C45) with the peak carbon number around C18.

Subsequently, OTAC was added into the dispersion and the dispersion was stirred vigorously at 60 C for 6 h. Resultant white sediments were separated by centrifugation and washed several times with deionized water (pH = 7) to ensure complete removal of free OTAC. Finally, the white sediments were vacuum dried at 80 C overnight and the obtained dried white sediments were the organic nano-clay. The composition and structure of the organic nano-clay were analyzed by FT-IR spectroscopy (Thermo Nicolet Co., USA) and X-ray diffraction (Nanotec Technology Co., Netherlands), respectively. sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of POA/clay nanocomposite PPD
sections.text:
POA/clay nanocomposite was prepared by toluene solvent blending. The solvent blending procedure is presented elsewhere [16]. The POA/nano-clay mass ratio was retained at 1:1 in order to facilitate intuitive comparison with neat POA. Composition and structure of the nanocomposite PPD were analyzed by FT-IR and XRD. Stability of POA/clay nanocomposite dispersed in dodecane (0.2 wt%) was also evaluated.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Gelation point test
sections.text: A temperature ramp test from 50 C to 10 C was utilized to probe the gel point of crude oil doped/undoped with PPD. The sample was cooled at a rate of 0.5 C/min while a constant shear stress of 0.01 Pa was imposed during cooling. Variation of shear rate with temperature was monitored and the gelation temperature is ascribed to a break to zero in the shear rate-temperature curve.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Flow curve test
sections.text: Crude oil doped/undoped with PPD was first cooled quiescently from 50 C to 5 C at a fixed cooling rate 0.5 C/min, and then maintained isothermally at 5 C for 20 min. Subsequently, flow curves of the crude oil were measured at 5 C by ramping the shear rate from 5 s 1 to 200 s 1 in a time span of 10 min. The measured variation of apparent viscosity with shear rate was recorded.

sections.heading: 2.4.3. Yield stress test
sections.text: Crude oil doped/undoped with PPD were first cooled quiescently from 50 C to 10 C at a fixed cooling rate 0.5 C/min, and then maintained isothermally at 10 C for 20 min. Subsequently, the yield stress was measured by ramping the imposed shear stress. The stress uploading rate was fixed at 5 Pa/min.

sections.heading: 2.5. DSC test of Changqing waxy crude oil
sections.text: Exothermic phase changes occurring in undoped/doped crude oil were studied by a DSC 821e calorimeter (Mettler-Toledo Co., Switzerland) to determine the WAT of crudes [23,24]. The temperature scanning range is 85 to 20 C. A fixed cooling rate of 10 C/ min was utilized, which was the most sensitive test rate of the instrument, due to the large associated heat flow.

sections.heading: 2.6. Microscopic observation of Changqing waxy crude oil
sections.text: A polarizable microscopic OLYMPUS BX51 (Olympus Co., Japan) fitted with a Linkam LTS350 automatic thermal stage (Linkam Scientific Instruments Ltd, UK) was used to observe wax crystals precipitated from the crude oil [25,26]. After being pre-heated to 60 C for same time, one droplet of the crude oil sample was transferred to a glass slide covered by a coverslip. The loaded crude oil samples were cooled from 50 C to 0 C in the stage with a fixed cooling rate 0.5 C/min. The observed morphology of the precipitated wax crystals was recorded during the cooling process. Quantitative analysis of microscopic images were carried out by the software OLYCIA p3 (OLYMPUS professional image analyzer) and three key parameters, total number of wax crystals (Nwc), average equal-area-circle diameter of wax crystals (Deac) and fractal dimension of wax crystals (D) were obtained. Nwc and Deac represent the number and size of precipitated wax crystals, respectively. D represents structural complexity and space-filling (occlusion) ability of the wax crystals, and was quantified by the box counting method [23,27].

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Dispersibility of organic nano-clay
sections.text:
Original and organic nano-clay were dispersed in water and dodecane solvents, respectively, at a concentration of 0.2 wt%. The dispersed samples were maintained quiescently at room temperature for 1 h; subsequently, the stability of the samples was evaluated. As shown in Fig. 3a, unmodified nano-clay is well dispersed in water but sediments quickly in dodecane, in accordance with the hydrophilic nature of clay. In contrast, organic nano-clay is well dispersed in dodecane but sediments quickly in water (Fig. 3b), consistent with an oleophilic nature. Fig. 3c and d show that organic nano-clay is dispersible in dodecane in the form of flocs with sizes in the range of 8–80 lm and mean size of 30 lm. It may be concluded nano-clay changes nature from hydrophilic to oleophilic after OTAC intercalation.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Effect of organic nano-clay on rheology of crude oil
sections.text:
The influence of solely organic nano-clay on the gelation point and measured flow curves (at 5 C) of Changqing crude oil was assessed by rheometric means. As illustrated in Supporting Information Fig. S4, both the gelation point (from 25.2 C to 25.5 C) and the apparent viscosity at 5 C increases slightly upon addition of 400 mg/kg organic clay. In addition, the effect of solely organic nano-clay on the morphology of precipitated wax crystals (at 0 C) is shown in Fig. S5. It is obvious that the organic nano-clay alone brings little influences to the wax crystals morphology. Despite the large presence of OTAC molecules (with C18 alkyl chains) fixed on the outer surface and interlayer of the organic nano-clay, the organic clay is not able to function as a pour point depressant nor change the precipitation habit of the wax crystals. Addition of organic nano-clay alone slightly aggravates the rheology of the crude oil.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Composition and structural analysis
sections.text: FT-IR spectra of the POA/clay nanocomposite PPD is shown in Fig. 2a, which displays characteristic absorption bands at 2920 cm 1 (ACH3 characteristic peak), 925 cm 1, 1465 cm 1 and 2855 cm 1 (ACH2A characteristic peak), 1735 cm 1 (C@O stretching in ester), and 1175 cm 1 (CAOAC stretching). Absorption bands associated with original nano-clay at 1100 cm 1 and 474 cm 1 are well retained. X-ray diffraction spectra associated with POA and POA/clay nanocomposite PPD are shown in Fig. 2b. In the diffraction angle region of 3 –15 (2h), a sharp peak at 4.2330 is evident from the POA/clay nanocomposite, indicating a d001 spacing of 2.087 nm. In comparison to the d001 value (1.964 nm) of organic nano-clay, the interlayer spacing of nanoclay in POA/clay nanocomposite is slightly increased. Therefore, an intercalated or hierarchical morphology of POA/clay nanocomposite was obtained [29].

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Dispersibility of POA/clay nanocomposite PPD
sections.text:
When POA/clay nanocomposite is dispersed into dodecane at 0.2 wt%, the resulting fluid state is a homogeneous dispersion with no apparent sedimentation observed after 3 h at room temperature (see Fig. 4a). From Fig. 4b and c, it is evident that POA/clay nanocomposite is dispersed in dodecane as small particles with sizes ranging from 2 to 12 lm and a mean size of 6 lm. In comparison to organic nano-clay-dodecane dispersion, POA/clay nanocomposite dispersed in dodecane are smaller and more stable. It is deduced that POA molecules adsorb on the outer surface and interlayers of nano-clay and further increase the nano-clay particle lipophilicity.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effects of POA/clay nanocomposite PPD on rheology
3.3.1. Gelation point
sections.text:
The influence of POA and POA/clay nanocomposite PPD on the gelation point of Changqing crude is shown in Fig. 5a and b and Table 2. The gelation point is reduced in a conventional manner with increasing POA concentration. The gelation point of undoped crude oil is 26.2 C. The measured gelation point decreases to 25.2 C upon addition of 50 mg/kg POA and is further depressed to 24.6 C at a POA concentration of 100 mg/kg. The gelation point is 21.4 C at 200 mg/kg POA and is 19.0 C at 400 mg/kg POA.
Prepared POA/clay nanocomposites consist of 50 wt% POA and 50 wt% organic nano-clay. Therefore, crude oil doped with 200 mg/kg POA is appropriately comparable to crude oil doped with 400 mg/kg nanocomposite (200 mg/kg POA + 200 mg/kg organic nano-clay), as the overall POA contents are identical. In comparison to neat POA, the POA/clay nanocomposite PPD demonstrates a stronger ability to depress the gelation point. The gelation point is 23.7 C upon addition of 100 mg/kg nanocomposite PPD. At 200 mg/kg nanocomposite PPD, the gelation point is further reduced to 23.0 C. The gelation point is 18.0 C at 400 mg/kg nanocomposite PPD and is 17.2 C at 800 mg/kg nanocomposite PPD.

Apparent viscosity values measured at various shear rates are shown in Table 2 (the average viscosity reducing rate I is compared with oil undoped and II is compared with oil doped with same content of POA). The apparent viscosity is substantially reduced after addition of POA or POA/clay nanocomposite PPD. At comparable POA content, POA/clay nanocomposite PPD has a much stronger viscosity reduction performance than neat POA. The average viscosity reduction after addition of 50 mg/kg POA is 6.43%, while the average viscosity reduction after addition of 100 mg/kg nanocomposite PPD (containing 50 mg/kg POA and 50 mg/kg organic nano-clay) is 27.06%. Compared to 50 mg/kg POA, 100 mg/kg nanocomposite PPD further reduces crude oil viscosity by 21.99%. The dramatic observed flowability beneficiation of nano-clay becomes even more evident at POA contents of 200 mg/kg and 400 mg/kg, with additional viscosity reduction ascribed to the presence of nano-clay quantified as 25.50% and 33.75%, respectively.
The effect of rest time on viscosity reduction performance of the PPDs was evaluated by an equilibrium viscosity test at 50 s 1 and 5 C. As seen in Supporting information Table S1, the observed rheological beneficiation of POA/clay nanocomposite is more persistent and lasting than pure POA, at comparable overall POA contents.

sections.heading: 3.4. DSC curves
sections.text:
DSC curves of waxy crude undoped/doped with POA and POA/clay nanocomposite PPDs are shown in Fig. 6, providing a quantitative measure of the WAT. As temperature is progressively reduced, the heat flux signal gradually decreases and then increases sharply due to the paraffin wax precipitation phase change. The WAT is quantitatively defined as the temperature at which the heat flow signal deviates from the liquid state heat capacity trend. From the DSC curves, the WAT of the original crude oil is measured at 36 C. When 200 mg/kg and 400 mg/kg POA are added, the WAT drops to 33 C and 32 C, respectively. When 400 mg/kg and 800 mg/kg POA/clay nanocomposite are added, the WAT increases to 34 C and 35 C, respectively. POA reduces the WAT, while POA/clay nanocomposite PPD exhibits an opposing effect. Based on crystallization theory, a waxy crystal may exist in a stable condition with growth only when its nucleus radius exceeds the critical nucleation radius rk, which may be expressed as follows:
rk ¼ 2rl sMTeqDHpDT ð1Þ
where rl s is the interfacial tension between new wax crystals and liquid phase, M is the molecular mass of wax, Te is the equilibrium transformation temperature, q denotes the paraffin wax crystal density, DHp denotes wax precipitation enthalpy and DT is the super-cooling degree. As reported in several literatures [3,8,10,30], polymeric PPDs serve to simultaneously increase rl s and decrease DHp, effectively increasing the critical nucleation radius as well as the nucleation potential barrier of wax crystals, promoting the effective (but not equilibrium) solubility of wax molecules in the oil phase, thereby inhibiting wax precipitation. The presence of organic nano-clay promotes wax crystal nucleation by providing heterogeneous nucleation sites, thereby circumventing the effective solubilizing effect relevant to neat POA. Hence, the observed WAT value recovers with an increasing additive concentration of POA/clay nanocomposite PPD.

sections.heading: 3.5. Microscopic observation
sections.text:
Microscopic images of crude oil undoped/doped with POA and POA/clay nanocomposite PPD at 20 C and 0 C are shown in Fig. 7. In the unmodified crude oil, precipitated wax crystals are small and highly abundant, but exist in a haphazard arrangement (Fig. 7a and b).
After addition of 400 mg/kg POA, the wax crystal morphology changes into larger flocs and becomes more regular while the crystal number density is substantially reduced, thus, the solid–liquid interfacial area decreases (Fig. 7c and d). When wax crystals are modified by POA, continuous network formation is hindered, promoting rheological beneficiation at temperature conditions below WAT. However, at 400 mg/kg POA, the structure of the wax crystal flocs appear to be quite loose (occluding oil) instead of compact and also a large number of fine wax crystals are evident in the images.
After addition of 800 mg/kg POA/clay nanocomposite PPD (Fig. 7e and f), the size of the precipitated wax crystals in the crude oil continuously increases, and the structure of the wax crystal flocs may become more compact and regular, occluding a smaller fraction of oil. In addition, there is an almost complete absence of fine wax crystals in the oil benefitted with nanocomposite PPD. The increased size and compactness of wax crystals favor the further improvement of crude oil rheology.
Based on Fig. 7, characteristic parameters of the precipitated wax crystals are obtained and shown in Table 3. These characteristic parameters elucidate morphological variation of the wax crystals before/after the addition of PPDs. sections.heading: 3.6. Mechanism of POA/clay nanocomposite PPD
sections.text:
Neat POA acts as an effective PPD for waxy crude oil by promoting the solubility of wax molecules in oil phase and modify the wax crystal morphology to larger flocs through adsorption and cocrystallization effects.
According to Table S1, POA/clay nanocomposite PPD shows improved viscosity reduction than pure POA at various rest times, indicating that POA molecules interact strongly with the organic nano-clay and are difficult to desorb. A possible heterogeneous nucleation mechanism for the POA/clay nanocomposite PPD is proposed in the current work (see Fig. 8). It appears that the POA/clay nanocomposite particles dispersed in crude oil may effectively provide nano/micro sized solid–liquid interface sites (average size around 6 lm, see Fig. 4) as wax precipitation templates, which
Please cite this article in press as: Yao B et al. Organically modified nano-cla (2015), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.fuel.2015.10.114
result in larger and more compact wax morphologies (average size around 10 lm, see Fig. 7). The large size (reduction of solid–liquid interfacial area) and compact structure (less occluded oil) of the wax crystals are adverse for the formation of a strong gel network structure. Therefore, the rheological flowability properties of waxy crude oil are further improved.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In this article, POA/clay nanocomposite PPD is successfully prepared by dispersing the organic nano-clays in POA PPD matrix. It is found that POA molecules increase the lipophilicity of nano-clay further and POA molecules strongly interact with the organic nano-clay and are hard to desorb from the surface of clay particles. The effect of the POA/clay nanocomposite PPD on the rheology and wax crystal precipitation habit of Changqing waxy crude oil are well studied. A possible heterogeneous nucleation mechanism for the POA/clay nanocomposite PPD is proposed here that the POA/clay nanocomposite particles dispersed in crude oil effectively provide micro sized solid–liquid interface sites as wax precipitation templates, which results in larger and more compact wax morphologies. And the large size (reducing the wax crystal/oil interface) and compact structure (less liquid oil is entrapped in the wax crystal structure) of the wax crystals are adverse for the formation of a network structure and favor the rheological properties improvement of waxy crude oil.

metadata.abstractText: Introduction of nanomaterials constitutes a novel and efficient means to enhance the performance of polymeric pour point depressants (PPDs). Based on the specific layered structure and favorable cationic exchange characteristics of nano-clay particles in the presence of charged organic compounds, an original hydrophilic nano-clay is first modified by octadecyltrimethyl ammonium chloride (OTAC) and then bypolyoctadecylacrylate (POA). The modified nano-clay serves as an effective nanocomposite PPD. Compared to an identical content of POA, addition of POA/clay nanocomposite PPD to Changqing waxy crude oil improves the rheological properties while elevating the wax appearance temperature of the oil. Polarized microscope observation shows that POA/clay nanocomposites provide wax nucleation sites upon which wax molecules assemble and precipitate. Addition of POA/clay nanocomposite PPD results in larger and more compact crystal morphology, thus inhibiting the formation of a network structure, and further improving rheological properties of waxy crude oil. 63 64 65 66 67 68 69 70 a r t i c l e i n f o Article history: Received 19 July 2015 Received in revised form 8 October 2015 Accepted 28 October 2015 Available online xxxx
